Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> The first fix should have been a warning to you:  you made a quick change,
> thought you were done, shipped the new version and then someone else pointed
> out that your fix had created a deeper, more subtle bug.

The change was neither quick nor simple. It was actually a rather 
involved reworking of the code to add a new feature. I'm not hugely 
surprised that in the new code that was added there was an undiscovered 
bug since that part of the code had not yet been through the full 
process the older parts of XOM have gone through (code review, static 
code analysis, code coverage measurements, etc.)

> Well, yes, if you assume that your tests are 100% perfect.  They were not
> the first time, why do you assume they are now?

Any time someone starts using words like "perfect" or "100%", alarm 
bells go off in my head. It's never a question of perfect or 100%. It's 
a question of better or worse. My argument is that test-driven 
programming is better.  It produces more robust, less-buggy code than 
traditional approaches based on attempts to understand without actually 
verifying that understanding.

Yes, it would probably be better if I did understand exactly why the fix 
worked but:

1. If I waited to understand it, it would take much longer to actually 
produce the fix.

2. If I had focused on understanding the fix, I might not have found it 
in the first place. My theoretical understanding wwas pointing at a much 
more complicated solution. It's easier to figure out why something you 
know works does work, than it is to figure out what will work.

3. (and this is a point a lot of people are missing) XOM is at most a 
medium sized code base. One person probably could understand all of it 
given a finite amount of time. However, there is an increasing amount of 
code for which only a heuristic and experimental understanding is possible.

My argument is that there is hope, and that truly large, convoluted, and 
  opaque code bases are nonetheless practically fixable and 
maintainable, despite the lack of understanding.

> Don't you have enough proof that you are overestimating the
> comprehensiveness of these tests since they failed to catch two bugs in a
> short period of time?

My tests did not fail to catch two bugs in a short period of time. There 
was only one bug (at least found so far) and it was in a newly 
implemented feature. Nothing will be perfect the first go round. That's 
why we do beta testing and code review and so forth. I'm frankly 
surprised there haven't been more bugs found in the new parts; but it's 
probably that they haven't received extensive shakedowns yet.

By contrast in the two months since XOM 1.1 was released, there has been 
exactly one minor bug found in it (I wasn't checking for null where I 
should have been. See 
http://cafe.elharo.com/java/a-minor-glitch-in-type-safe-enums/ .) That's 
pretty damn good. It's certainly much better than competing products 
like JDOM can claim. Complex programs can never be perfect but they can 
asymptotically approach perfection.
